[[Memphis, Tennessee]], [[Tennessee]], United States | instrument = [[Human voice|Vocals]], [[guitar]] | genre = [[Texas blues]], [[country blues]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[guitarist]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = | label = [[Paramount Records|Paramount]], [[Victor Talking Machine Company|Victor]] | associated_acts = [[Jesse Thomas (musician)|Jesse Thomas]] | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Ramblin' Thomas''' (1902–1945){{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p32702/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Ramblin' Thomas |author=Chadbourne, Eugene |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=January 30, 2010}} was an [[United States|American]] [[country blues]] [[singing|singer]], [[guitarist]] and [[songwriter]].{{cite book | first= Paul | last= Du Noyer | year= 2003 | title= The Illustrated Encyclopedia of Music | edition= 1st | publisher= Flame Tree Publishing | location= Fulham, London | isbn= 1-904041-96-5 | page= 181}} He was the brother of another blues musician, [[Jesse Thomas (musician)|Jesse Thomas]]. Thomas is best remembered for his [[slide guitar]] playing, and [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] several pieces in the late 1920s and early 1930s.{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | isbn= 1-85868-255-X | page= 110}} Blues scholars seem undecided if Thomas's [[nickname]] of Ramblin' was in reference to his style of playing, or itinerant nature.{{cite book | first= David | last= Evans | year= 2008 | title= Ramblin' on my Mind: New Perspectives on the Blues | edition= | publisher= University of Illinois Press | location= Illinois | isbn= 978-0-252-03203-5 | page= 195}} ==Biography== '''Willard Thomas''' was born in [[Logansport, Louisiana|Logansport]], [[Louisiana]], one of nine children. His father played the [[fiddle]], and three brothers Joe L., [[Jesse Thomas (musician)|Jesse]], and Willard learnt to play the guitar, with Willard particularly practising slide guitar techniques. Thomas relocated to [[Deep Ellum, Dallas, Texas]] in the late 1920s, and was influenced by the playing of [[Lonnie Johnson (musician)|Lonnie Johnson]]. He performed in [[San Antonio]], [[Oklahoma]] and possibly [[St. Louis, Missouri]] in his subsequent travels. Thomas recorded in both [[Dallas]] and [[Chicago]] between 1928 and 1932, for [[Paramount Records]] and [[Victor Talking Machine Company|Victor Records]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wirz.de/music/thorafrm.htm |title=Ramblin' Thomas discography |publisher=Wirz.de |accessdate=2014-01-28}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rootsandrhythm.com/roots/BLUES%20&%20GOSPEL/blues_t3.htm |title=Blues & Gospel - Sonny Terry -> Ramblin' Thomas |publisher=Rootsandrhythm.com |date=1952-08-15 |accessdate=2014-01-28}} Thomas reportedly died of [[tuberculosis]] in 1945 in [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]], [[Tennessee]].
